channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Triad Links to Attack on Protesters Raise Some Old Questions
item.description: Pro-democracy protesters have accused Hong Kong law enforcement of cooperating with shadowy criminals at the behest of Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN

item.title: South and North Korea Agree to Resume High-Level Talks
item.description: A breakthrough appeared to come Saturday, during a meeting between South Korean officials and a delegation from the North visiting for the closing ceremony of the Asian Games.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Anger Simmers in Hong Kong After Attacks on Protest Camps
item.description: Confrontation returned to the Mong Kok area on Saturday, a day after demonstrators came under attack by men who the police say had underworld ties.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Scuffling broke out again Saturday in the Mong Kok district of Hong Kong between pro-democracy protesters, at right, and men assailing their encampment in Nathan Road, a major thoroughfare. Nineteen men were arrested in connection with an attack Friday night on protesters in the same neighborhood.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Color Revolution’ in China a ‘Daydream,’ People’s Daily Tells Protesters
item.description: In its third commentary in three days on the Hong Kong protests, the Chinese Communist Party mouthpiece warned Saturday of “turmoil” if the rule of law is not respected.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: In Unusual Trip, North Korean Aides Attend Games in South
item.description: Three trusted aides to the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un arrived in South Korea on Saturday to attend the closing ceremony of the Asian Games in a highly unusual trip.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Judge Orders Disclosure of Guantánamo Videos
item.description: A federal judge cited the First Amendment in overriding the government’s argument for keeping secret classified tapes showing the forced feeding of a detainee.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Clashing Visions of Conservation Shake Brazil’s Presidential Vote
item.description: Satellite data shows that Brazil’s annual deforestation rate in the Amazon is rising again after years of declines.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: ISIS Releases Video of Execution of British Aid Worker
item.description: The militants have released another video of a beheading — this one of a middle-aged British aid worker who was abducted last year in Syria
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: A Plan to Use Survivors’ Blood for Ebola Treatment in Africa
item.description: The World Health Organization has issued guidance in West Africa on collecting convalescent blood or plasma for transfusion, but there are obstacles.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK
item.media:description: Health authorities hope to recruit survivors, like Julius Prout, to donate blood that might be used to treat people who are still sick.

item.title: Serge Schmemann: A Week Dominated by Hong Kong, Ebola and the Secret Service
item.description: Much of the news in the past week was about security and its failures.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong on Friday.

item.title: Listening Post: An Inconvenient Protest for Both China and the U.S.
item.description: Demonstrations in Hong Kong put the Obama administration in the awkward position of wanting to support pro-democracy forces without alienating a key partner.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Under Francis, Catholic Leaders Prepare to Debate Whether Church Should Change
item.description: A meeting convened by Pope Francis will begin a process on whether the Roman Catholic Church will change its approach to issues like divorce, gay civil unions or single parents.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Coalition Leader Warns of Long Fight Against ISIS in Iraq
item.description: John R. Allen said it would take up to a year to prepare the Iraqi military for a campaign to retake Mosul, which is held by ISIS.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Mali: Gunmen Kill 9 U.N. Peacekeepers
item.description: Gunmen on motorbikes ambushed a convoy of United Nations peacekeepers in northern Mali on Friday, United Nations officials said, killing nine.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Nigeria: Grisly Claim by Boko Haram
item.description: The extremist Islamist group Boko Haram has released a video that shows charred plane wreckage and the beheading of a man identified as a pilot of a missing Nigerian Air Force jet.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Thailand: 2 Arrested in Tourists’ Deaths
item.description: Two migrant workers from Myanmar were arrested on Friday after the police said they had confessed to killing two British tourists.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: At Least 30 Killed in Stampede at Religious Festival in India
item.description: With tens of thousands attending the festival, in the eastern state of Bihar, federal officials questioned whether the local government had taken adequate safety steps.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Canadian Premier Asks Parliament to Approve Airstrikes on ISIS
item.description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper said the operation would initially last only six months and would not involve combat by ground troops.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Sweden to Recognize Palestinian State
item.description: The new prime minister announced the decision in Parliament on Friday, making Sweden the first major state of the European Union to recognize Palestine.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: U.N. Report Details ISIS Abuse of Women and Children
item.description: Among the atrocities were the kidnapping of a girl, who was raped and sold into sex slavery, and children as young as 12 forced to become soldiers.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY MARCUS

item.title: U.N. Report Details ISIS Abuse of Yazidi Women and Children
item.description: Among the atrocities was the kidnapping of a girl, who was raped and sold into sex slavery, and children as young as 12 forced to become soldiers.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY MARCUS

item.title: News: Latest Updates From Hong Kong Protests
item.description: Crowds at the main protest site are growing but the streets around government offices are deserted.
item.dc:creator: By PHILIP PAN and ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Violence Erupts in Hong Kong as Protesters Are Assaulted
item.description: Protesters in several districts came under attack on Friday from men seeking to break apart their sit-ins, tearing down tents and surrounding demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY, AUSTIN RAMZY and EDWARD WONG

item.title: Bulgarians Set to Return to the Polls
item.description: Voters in one of the European Union’s poorest countries worry that another fragmented Parliament will make it harder to revive growth and tackle corruption.
item.dc:creator: By MARIANA IONOVA

item.title: Britain Names New Director of MI6 Spy Agency
item.description: Alex Younger will lead MI6, known officially as the Secret Intelligence Service, where he has worked since 1991.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
